narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was a small seminar so it really helped us practice close reading, thinking on our feet to respond quickly, and speaking up. It also asked us to think about Black religions as really intersectional. Some of the religions and movements we studied were ones I wasn't familiar with at all, so I appreciate learning about them even more. We also stretched our understanding of Black religion-- how it can operate almost secularly, or how it might have political aims but pretend to shun politics. Discussions/assignments definitely helped me to be a more critical reader.

Better understanding of the interconnected histories of black religion and politics, mainly in the US. A historical overview as well as grounding literature in the field. The last aspect of the course focused more deeply on cultural aspects.
I developed my understanding of Black religion and the tools used in the historical analysis of Black religions in America and beyond.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really liked the creative assignments! They were definitely a strength of the course and helped break up all the other assignments I was assigned in other classes. Wish assignments gave us more room to develop our ideas.  Another strength was the way Professor Turner kept us engaged with the readings through discussion activities and even bringing in the authors-- it's one of the first classes I've been in where we had authors visit.

Strengths= LOVED the discussions, and they were structured well and very intimate in our small group. Also I really enjoyed the assignments, which didn't all fit the same style but offered different options for demonstrating your understanding. I felt the assignments really helped me to explore the core concepts in new ways.

Weaknesses = could be the pandemic talking, but sometimes the readings felt very long. At times I struggled to connect the readings to each other, because of the density of the texts.

Strengths: The readings, guest speakers, and creative assignments
Weakness: Some of the class didnt seem very engaged and I wonder if a shift in format would have been necessary

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Again, Professor Turner took advantage of the digital format to bring in guest speakers. She was also really understanding of any tech issues and offered extensions if we had extenuating circumstances. Was never a stressful course, even though we were tackling a lot of material, and since it was such a difficult fall I really appreciate that.
Zoom. Was fine, breakout rooms worked great. More breaks and asynchronous offerings may have been nice, although I think we did the best we could have.
Overall, this course did a good job practicing the flexibility necessary for a time like this.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, would recommend this course! It's a really unique class because we had people from all different majors and class years, and everyone was able to participate and bring their own experience to the table for better discussion. I learned a lot about both Black religion/politics today and in the past, and a lot of material that isn't going to be covered in other history courses.
Yes! Absolutely, it felt so relevant to events outside of this class. Take this course and see your world with new eyes.
Yes, it is one of the few chances a student will get to study Black Religion and it does a good job introducing and interrogating the subject matter.
